text: THE artist commenced his narrative in the following terms:--
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: "I was bred a blacksmith, and knew my art as well as e'er a
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: black-thumbed, leathern-aproned, swart-faced knave of that noble
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: mystery. But I tired of ringing hammer-tunes on iron stithies, and went
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: wished to have the aid of an apprentice in his noble mystery. I served
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: him for six years, until I was master of my trade--I refer myself to
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth

author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: The two nobles who at present stood as rivals in her favour possessed
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: which was quelled, in a great measure, by his military talents. He was,
title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: appearance, and manners. The attire of the elder gentleman, a person
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: as it seemed of quality and in the prime of life, was very plain and
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: soldierlike, his stature low, his limbs stout, his bearing ungraceful,
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: twenty, or upwards, was clad in the gayest habit used by persons of
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: quality at the period, wearing a crimson velvet cloak richly ornamented
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: time--that is, it was combed upwards, and made to stand as it were on
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: end; and in his ears he wore a pair of silver earrings, having each a
title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: a decided and the fire of an enterprising character, the power of
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: reflection, and the promptitude of determination.
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: Both these gentlemen reclined nearly in the same posture on benches
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

title: Kenilworth

author: Scott, Walter

text: At the entrance of Tressilian both started from their musing, and

author: Scott, Walter

text: Drummond's Collection, but is evidently not of his composition:--
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: EPITAPH ON THE ERLE OF LEISTER.
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: Here lies a valiant warriour,
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: Who never drew a sword;
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: Here lies a noble courtier,
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: Who never kept his word;
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: Here lies the Erle of Leister,
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: Who governed the Estates,
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: Whom the earth could never living love,
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter

text: And the just Heaven now hates.
title: Kenilworth
author: Scott, Walter
